groups.reasoning: These all refer to the general practice of implementing circular economy approaches in construction/deconstruction. 'Culture' and 'Transition' are aspects of the broader practice.

members: Basic level training in circular economy principles [Instrument]
groups.reasoning: Both refer to the same training practice. Training is something people DO (a Practice), not a policy instrument.

members: Lack of regulation on circular economy [Barrier]
Barrier: Lack of Regulation on Circular Economy [Barrier]
groups.reasoning: All three refer to the same barrier: absence of regulatory frameworks for circular economy.

groups.canonical_label: Lack of Understanding of Circular Economy
members: Lack of Understanding of Circular Economy [Barrier]
groups.reasoning: Distinct barrier related to knowledge gaps.
Specific requirement for designer skills/knowledge.
Specific measurable requirements or goals within policies.
These refer to the same national-level policy framework, with '2024' being a dated version.

groups.canonical_label: ACT Circular Economy Strategy and Action Plan
members: ACT Circular Economy Strategy and Action Plan [Instrument]
groups.reasoning: Specific jurisdiction-level policy instrument for Australian Capital Territory.
A specific stakeholder group involved in circular economy governance.
Both refer to measurable outcomes of circular economy implementation.
Specific legislative instrument.
Both refer to action/implementation plans as policy instruments. These are essentially the same type of document.
Specific guidance document/instrument.
Specific guidance or knowledge resource document.
Specific design practice approach.
Business models that enable circular economy. While one is typed as Practice, business models are fundamentally enablers that facilitate circular practices.
Generic references to policy instruments and strategies at various levels.
Specific policy statement document.
Specific strategic planning document.
Specific program or mechanism (instrument) for facilitating transition.

groups.canonical_label: Circular Economy Principles for Building Design
members: Circular Economy Principles for Building Design [Instrument]
groups.reasoning: Both refer to guidance/frameworks for designers applying circular economy principles.

members: Construction and Demolition Resources and Waste [MaterialAsset]
groups.reasoning: All refer to the same physical materials/waste streams generated from construction and demolition activities. These are the actual material assets, not the management practices.
These are identical practices with slightly different abbreviations (CDW vs CDWM), both referring to the overall management approach for C&D waste.
Standalone practice - specific method of handling C&D waste through reuse.
Standalone practice - specific method of handling C&D waste through recycling, distinct from reuse.
Standalone requirement - an obligation to minimize waste generation.
Standalone requirement - obligation to justify demolition decisions.
Standalone practice - specific method of carefully dismantling buildings to recover materials, distinct from traditional/mechanical demolition.
Standalone practice - general demolition activity, parent concept to specific demolition types.

groups.canonical_label: Best Practices for Reducing, Reusing, and Recycling Construction and Demolition Materials
members: Best Practices for Reducing, Reusing, and Recycling Construction and Demolition Materials [Instrument]
groups.reasoning: Standalone instrument - a specific named guidance document or standard.
Standalone stakeholder - category of actors involved in demolition activities.
Standalone practice - specific method using machinery, distinct from selective demolition.

groups.canonical_label: Construction and Demolition (C&D) Waste Diversion Rate
members: Construction and Demolition (C&D) Waste Diversion Rate [OutcomeMetric]
groups.reasoning: Standalone metric - measures percentage of waste diverted from landfill.
Standalone metric - measures decrease in waste generation, distinct from diversion rate.
Standalone instrument - likely a LEED or similar certification credit/requirement.

groups.canonical_label: Construction and Demolition Waste Management Plans (C&D WMPs)
members: Construction and Demolition Waste Management Plans (C&D WMPs) [Instrument]
groups.reasoning: Standalone instrument - specific required planning documents for waste management.
Standalone practice - conventional demolition approach, distinct from selective or mechanical methods.

These all refer to the same practice of designing and constructing buildings with circular economy principles. 'Circular Design' is the most concise canonical form, as it encompasses the design approach that enables circular construction.
This is a distinct practice specifically focused on housing construction with circular economy principles, separate from general circular design.
This represents specific principles or requirements that guide circular design practice.
This is a specific planning requirement or deliverable for circular construction projects.

groups.canonical_label: Circular Design Standards for Built Environment
members: Circular Design Standards for Built Environment [Requirement]
groups.reasoning: This represents specific standards/requirements for the built environment sector, distinct from consumer products.

groups.canonical_label: Circular Design Standards for Consumer Products
members: Circular Design Standards for Consumer Products [Requirement]
groups.reasoning: This is outside the built environment domain but represents distinct standards for consumer products.
This is a specific named policy instrument establishing national-level standards.
This is a specific framework instrument for evaluating circular construction.
This is a specific policy instrument governing circular construction.

members: Circular Design in the Built Environment [Instrument]
groups.reasoning: Both refer to framework instruments that guide circular design implementation in the built environment.
This is a specific documentation instrument required for projects.
This represents a measurable outcome or KPI for circular economy implementation.
These are specific tools and resources that enable circular design practice.
This represents obstacles to implementing circular economy in construction.
Both refer to factors that facilitate or support circular economy implementation in construction.

These all refer to the same type of formal planning document/instrument used in construction projects. 'Waste Management Plan' is the standard term in construction governance. The singular/plural variations and 'Resource and Waste Management Plan' are the same instrument type.

groups.canonical_label: State and Territory Waste Management Plans
members: State and Territory Waste Management Plans [Instrument]
groups.reasoning: This is a distinct instrument referring to jurisdiction-level strategic plans, separate from project-level waste management plans.

groups.canonical_label: Queensland Waste Management and Resource Recovery Strategy
members: Queensland Waste Management and Resource Recovery Strategy [Instrument]
groups.reasoning: This is a specific named state-level policy instrument, distinct from generic waste management plans.
This is a distinct stakeholder category referring to companies/organizations that provide waste management services.

groups.canonical_label: Waste Management and Resource Recovery Sector
members: Waste Management and Resource Recovery Sector [Stakeholder]
groups.reasoning: This refers to the broader industry sector as a stakeholder category, distinct from specific providers.

These all refer to the same operational practice of managing, processing, and recovering waste and resources during construction/deconstruction activities. They describe the same core practice with slightly different terminology.

These all refer to the same core practice of reusing materials in construction/deconstruction. The variations with 'recycling' and 'recovery' are essentially describing the same practice domain, as reuse is the primary activity and recycling is typically bundled with it in practice.
This is a measurable outcome metric tracking the rate or amount of material reuse achieved. Renamed to clarify it measures the rate/percentage, not the practice itself.
This is a specific obligation or mandate requiring materials to be recyclable and reusable. Distinct from the practice itself.
This is a specific required deliverable/document that must be produced, distinct from the practice of reusing materials or analyzing potential.
This is a distinct analytical practice/method used to assess potential for reuse and recycling, separate from the actual reuse practice itself.

members: National Strategy for Waste and Recycling [Instrument]
groups.reasoning: These all refer to Australia's national-level waste policy instrument. 'National Waste Strategy 2018' and 'National Strategy for Waste and Recycling' are likely the same document (the official name is 'National Waste Policy' with various iterations including the 2018 strategy). These are the same policy instrument at the national level.
This is a distinct policy instrument focused specifically on waste avoidance, separate from the broader national waste policy.
This describes an approach or practice (focusing on recycling) rather than a specific named policy instrument. It remains as a Practice.
This refers to enforcement obligations or requirements related to waste regulations, distinct from the policy instruments themselves.

These all refer to the core practice of taking buildings apart. 'Safe Disassembly' is just a qualified version of the same practice. 'Disassembly' as a Requirement is too generic and is better captured as the Practice itself.
This is the specific practice of designing buildings to facilitate future disassembly. Standardizing to the common industry term 'Design for Disassembly' with DfD abbreviation.
Both refer to documented guidance/plans for how to disassemble a building. A disassembly manual is essentially a detailed disassembly plan. These are specific instruments that guide the practice.
This represents obstacles to performing disassembly. Renaming to be more concise while maintaining clarity.

Both refer to the same concept of technological methods/approaches for recycling materials. 'Advanced' is a qualifier that doesn't create a distinct entity. This is a Practice because it describes methods/approaches used in material processing.
Standalone entity representing the category of organizations and actors involved in recycling operations. Correctly typed as Stakeholder.
Standalone entity representing physical infrastructure for recycling. Correctly typed as MaterialAsset (physical resources/infrastructure).
Embodied carbon is a measurable outcome/KPI. 'Targets' for embodied carbon are still measuring the same metric - the target is just a threshold value of that metric.
Embodied energy is a distinct measurable outcome from embodied carbon, though related. It measures energy consumed rather than carbon emissions.

These all refer to the same core practice of designing buildings/components to be easily taken apart. 'Design for Disassembly' and 'Design for Deconstruction' are synonymous terms in the construction domain. The variations mentioning 'reuse' and 'adaptability' are describing aspects of the same fundamental practice. This is a Practice (something people DO in design), not an Instrument or Enabler.

This is a distinct concept referring to policy/regulatory requirements or mandates to create incentives for disassembly and reuse. It's about requiring incentive mechanisms, not the design practice itself.
This is a physical material/resource category - waste materials generated from construction activities. Stands alone as a distinct MaterialAsset.
This refers to specific named policies governing construction waste. Distinct from requirements or plans - this is the policy instrument itself.

Both refer to mandatory planning/management requirements for construction waste. 'Construction Waste Management' as a Requirement is essentially the same obligation as requiring minimisation plans - they represent the requirement to manage/minimize waste, not the policies themselves.

groups.canonical_label: Lack of Policy Specificity in Construction Waste Management
members: Lack of Policy Specificity in Construction Waste Management [Barrier]
groups.reasoning: This is a distinct barrier - the obstacle created when policies lack sufficient detail or specificity. Remains separate as it describes a challenge rather than the policies or requirements themselves.
Both refer to the same measurable outcome of reducing waste quantities. 'Waste Reduction Goal' is just a more specific phrasing of the same metric.
Distinct practice focused on avoiding waste generation at source. Stands alone as a specific approach.
Both refer to the same practice of recovering value from waste materials. 'Waste Recovery Technologies' is simply the technological means of implementing waste recovery, not a separate concept.

These are different editions/versions of the same recurring policy instrument. The 2020 and 2022 versions are specific iterations of the National Waste Report series. The canonical label represents the instrument series itself.

This is a data collection and reporting system/tool, which functions as an instrument (a structured framework for gathering information), not an Authority (which would be the organization that manages it). It's distinct from the National Waste Report, which likely draws data from this database.
This is a specific requirement or mandate regarding the proportion/amount of recycled materials that must be used - it's an obligation within instruments, not the materials themselves
This refers to the actual physical materials that have been recycled - a category of material assets used in construction
This is a specific subcategory of recycled materials (organic-based) - distinct from general recycled materials and should remain separate as it refers to a specific material type

All three refer to the same concept: EPR is a policy instrument/framework that makes producers responsible for end-of-life management of their products. While EPR creates requirements and influences practices, its PRIMARY function in governance is as a named policy instrument/mechanism. The 'Requirement:' prefix in one variant suggests it was extracted from a context describing EPR as a requirement, but EPR itself is the instrument that creates requirements.

These are the same concept - LCA is a standardized methodology/practice for assessing environmental impacts across a product's life cycle. It's something practitioners DO, making it a Practice rather than a Requirement.

WLCA is a distinct but related practice that extends LCA to include all life cycle stages with emphasis on the 'whole' building context. It's a specific methodology/practice, not a requirement itself. Kept separate from LCA as it represents a more comprehensive variant.
This is a specific, well-defined practice in construction referring to innovative building techniques including prefabrication and modular construction. It should remain as a distinct entity.

All three entities refer to the same practice of managing building materials in a circular manner (keeping materials in use, recovering value, reducing waste). They are different phrasings of the same concept. The canonical label 'Circular Materials Management' better captures this as a specific practice without invoking the overarching 'Circular Economy' paradigm as the primary term. This represents the actual practice/method of handling materials circularly in construction and deconstruction contexts.
This is a specific deconstruction practice involving careful dismantling of building components for reuse or recycling. It stands alone as a distinct practice.
This is a distinct barrier referring to the limited availability of landfill space, which is a physical constraint that hinders traditional waste disposal methods.

These refer to the same concept: the financial cost of landfilling waste. While initially labeled differently, high landfill costs/charges actually ENABLE circular practices by making deconstruction and material recovery more economically competitive. The Enabler type is correct because increased costs create economic incentives for alternative approaches.
Public procurement is the practice/process of government purchasing. It's an action that authorities undertake, not an instrument itself.
Procurement contracts are specific legal instruments that formalize purchasing agreements. They are distinct from the practice of procurement itself.

Procurement clauses are specific requirements or obligations embedded within procurement contracts. They represent mandates within instruments, making them distinct from both the practice and the contract instrument itself.
This is a specific practice/action of reusing materials, distinct from the materials themselves

Both refer to the same material asset category - materials recovered from existing buildings. 'Quality' is a descriptor but doesn't make it a different entity; it's the same material asset with quality as an attribute

These refer to the same governmental entity. 'Australian Government Agencies' is simply a more specific reference to the organizational units within the Australian Government. Since this is a specific named organization that creates/enforces instruments, the correct type is Authority. The canonical label should be 'Australian Government' as it's the proper name of the authority, with agencies being implicit subdivisions.

These refer to the same concept - the requirement for products to be certified. 'Product Certification' is the specific obligation/mandate that products must meet certain standards, making it a Requirement. The word 'Policies' in the second entity is redundant - the certification requirement itself is what matters, not a separate policy instrument about certification. The primary function is the obligation to certify products, not a named policy document.
The Repairability Index is a specific named policy instrument (e.g., France's mandatory labeling system). It is a formal tool/framework for measuring and communicating repairability.
Repairability as a standalone concept refers to the general obligation or design requirement that products/buildings be repairable. This is distinct from the specific Repairability Index instrument.
This is a specific named policy document from 2019, correctly typed as an Instrument
This is a design approach/methodology that practitioners implement, correctly typed as a Practice. It is distinct from the 2019 strategy document

These refer to the same concept - the practice of using connections that can be disassembled. 'Reversible connections' is the more concise canonical form. This is a Practice (a specific method/approach used in construction) rather than a Requirement (which would be an obligation within a specific instrument). The longer form 'and assembly methods' is redundant as reversible connections inherently involve assembly methods.

groups.canonical_label: Single-Case End-of-Waste Decision for Recycled Aggregates
members: Single-Case End-of-Waste Decision for Recycled Aggregates [Instrument]
groups.reasoning: This is a specific type of administrative decision that applies to individual cases

groups.canonical_label: National End-of-Waste Decision for Recycled Aggregates
members: National End-of-Waste Decision for Recycled Aggregates [Instrument]
groups.reasoning: This is a distinct instrument that applies at the national level, as opposed to single-case decisions. These are two different regulatory mechanisms for determining when recycled aggregates cease to be waste

members: Standard Building Contracts Specification of New Materials [Barrier]
groups.reasoning: These refer to the same concept - standard building contracts are contractual instruments used in construction. The first entity appears to describe a specific problematic aspect (specification of new materials) within these contracts that acts as a barrier to reuse, but the underlying entity is the contract instrument itself. The barrier is a characteristic of how the instrument is currently structured, not a separate entity.

Waste disposal is a general practice/method of handling waste materials. It's not a specific requirement (which would be something like 'must dispose of hazardous waste within 30 days'). This is a broad activity in construction/deconstruction.

Landfill disposal is correctly typed as a Barrier - it represents the obstacle of materials ending up in landfills rather than being reused/recycled. This is a distinct concept from general waste disposal, as it specifically refers to the problematic outcome that circular economy practices aim to avoid.
This is a specific named policy document or guideline - an Instrument
This is a procurement approach/method that organizations implement - a Practice distinct from the Guide instrument
This refers to the professional role/category of engineers as stakeholders in construction and deconstruction processes
This is a specific professional organization that sets standards and provides guidance for engineering practice in Australia - distinct from the general stakeholder category
This refers to the EU Waste Framework Directive (2008/98/EC), a primary EU-level policy instrument

This is a distinct UK statutory instrument that transposes the EU Waste Directive into UK law. While related to the Waste Directive, it is a separate legal instrument with its own specific provisions and jurisdiction

These refer to the same concept - specific mandated targets for recycling waste materials. 'Waste Recycling Targets' is more precise and complete, as recycling targets in the construction/deconstruction context specifically refer to waste materials. Both are requirements that set obligations for recycling rates.
This is a category of organizational actors involved in the domain, making it a Stakeholder type

groups.canonical_label: Donation via Charitable and Social Enterprises
members: Donation via Charitable and Social Enterprises [Practice]
groups.reasoning: This is a specific action/method for redistributing materials or assets, making it a Practice. It describes WHAT is done (donation) through WHO (charitable enterprises), but the practice itself is distinct from the stakeholder category
This is a geographic/political area where instruments apply - correctly typed as Jurisdiction

This is the governmental organization that creates/enforces instruments in the NT jurisdiction - correctly typed as Authority. These are distinct entities: one is the territory itself, the other is its governing body

These refer to the same concept. 'Design for Flexibility' is a specific design practice/approach in construction that enables future adaptability. While 'Flexibility' alone could be seen as a requirement, in the context of building deconstruction governance it refers to the same practice of designing buildings to be adaptable. The more specific 'Design for Flexibility' is the better canonical label, and Practice is the correct type as it describes a specific design method/approach that practitioners implement.
This is a distinct practice focused on designing buildings and components with circular economy principles in mind from the outset
This is a distinct practice focused on the construction/building phase with circular principles, separate from the design phase practice
This refers to the collection of technical standards and specifications published in Australia - these are policy instruments that set requirements
This is the organization that develops and publishes Australian Standards - it is the authority body responsible for creating the instruments

These refer to the same circular economy design principle - a specific action/approach used in construction. 'Design Out Waste and Pollution' is the complete formulation of the first principle from the Ellen MacArthur Foundation's circular economy framework. 'Design Out Waste' is a shortened version of the same concept. This is a Practice (something practitioners DO during design) rather than an Enabler (which would be a factor that supports practices).

These refer to the same concept - a digital passport is a specific tool/mechanism (often mandated by policy) for tracking material information throughout a building's lifecycle. It functions as an instrument in the governance context because it's a standardized system/framework for documentation and information management, not a practice (which would be the ACT of using or implementing it). The singular form with title case is more standard.
This is a distinct practice where materials/components are reused at a different location from where they were deconstructed

This is a distinct practice where materials/components are reused at the same site where they were deconstructed. These are two separate practices with different logistics, planning requirements, and applications

These refer to the same concept. 'Building Materials and Components' is more comprehensive and precise, as it explicitly includes both raw materials and assembled components used in construction, which is the complete scope of physical resources in building deconstruction.

These refer to the same concept - the financial cost of disposing of materials/waste. While high disposal costs can act as a barrier to certain practices, the entity itself is fundamentally a measurable economic outcome. The primary nature is as a metric (cost/fee amount), and its barrier effect is contextual. 'Disposal Costs' is the more comprehensive term that encompasses fees.
This refers to the physical equipment itself (HVAC, electrical, plumbing systems, etc.) - a material asset that can be reused
This refers to the action/method of reusing building services equipment - a distinct practice that involves the material asset but is not the asset itself
Refers to the physical structural components and assemblies of buildings - a material asset category
Refers to the practice/process of designing buildings - an action performed by professionals, distinct from the physical structures themselves
This is a specific type of cladding material that should remain distinct

This is a general category of building envelope materials. While 'Metal Cladding' is a specific type of cladding, they represent different levels of specificity and should remain separate - one is a specific material type, the other is a broader material category
This is a measurable metric tracking the count of derelict buildings, which is an outcome indicator for building stock management and deconstruction policy effectiveness
This refers to the actual physical buildings that are abandoned or in disrepair - these are material assets that may be candidates for deconstruction and material recovery
This refers to the specific practice/activity of salvaging materials and components from buildings during deconstruction
This refers to the category of actors (people/organizations) who perform salvage operations - they are distinct from the practice itself

Digital Twin is a practice/method of creating virtual representations of physical assets for monitoring and management, not a material asset itself. It's something people DO in construction/deconstruction.
Digital Twin Victoria is a specific named initiative/platform/framework in Victoria, Australia - correctly classified as an Instrument. This is distinct from the general practice of digital twinning.
Supply Chain represents a category of actors/organizations involved in the construction/deconstruction process - it's a stakeholder group

Integrated Supply Chain refers to a specific approach or method of coordinating supply chain activities - it's something organizations DO, making it a practice distinct from the general stakeholder category

groups.canonical_label: Keep Products and Materials in Use
members: Keep Products and Materials in Use [Enabler]
Keep Products and Materials in Use and Regenerate Nature [Practice]
groups.reasoning: Both refer to the same core circular economy practice of extending product/material lifecycles. The longer version includes 'Regenerate Nature' which is a separate principle. The core concept 'Keep Products and Materials in Use' is a specific action/approach in circular construction, making it a Practice. The shorter, more focused label is clearer and more commonly used in the domain.

These refer to the same concept - the traditional take-make-dispose economic model that acts as a barrier to circular economy and deconstruction practices. It is correctly typed as a Barrier because it represents the systemic obstacle that circular economy and building deconstruction seek to overcome. It is not a Practice (something people actively do), but rather the existing paradigm that prevents sustainable practices.
This is a specific barrier describing the lack of incentives for material reuse in the construction/deconstruction domain

This is a distinct enabler describing the presence of incentives. While related to the barrier above, they are opposite concepts - one describes the absence of incentives (barrier) and the other describes their presence (enabler). They should remain separate entities.

groups.canonical_label: Maintain the Value of Products and Materials
members: Keep Products and Materials in Use at Highest Value [Requirement]
Maintain the Value of Products and Materials [Practice]
groups.reasoning: These refer to the same circular economy principle of keeping materials in circulation at their highest utility. This is a Practice (something people DO in construction/deconstruction) rather than a Requirement (which would be a specific mandate within a policy instrument). The action of maintaining value through reuse, refurbishment, and recycling is a practice that supports circular economy goals.
Maintenance is a specific action/method performed in building management and deconstruction contexts

Maintenance Cycles refers to the measurable frequency or duration of maintenance activities, making it a metric rather than the practice itself. These are distinct concepts: one is the activity, the other is a temporal measurement of that activity
This refers to the problematic mixing of different waste types that prevents effective sorting and recycling - a specific obstacle in deconstruction and circular economy practices
This is a general term for flows of waste materials that can be managed, sorted, and potentially recovered as resources - distinct from the barrier of having them mixed

Material Efficiency refers to the practice of using materials optimally in construction/deconstruction processes. While it can be measured as an outcome, its primary function in governance is as a practice or approach that stakeholders implement. The metric would be something more specific like 'Material Efficiency Rate' or 'Percentage of Materials Reused'.

These refer to the same concept - the activity of identifying and categorizing materials. This is fundamentally a Practice (something people DO during deconstruction/construction processes) rather than a Requirement. The first label is more complete and descriptive, capturing both the identification and classification aspects of this practice.

These refer to the same concept - the practice of tracking materials through their lifecycle in construction/deconstruction. This is an ACTION/METHOD (tracking materials), not a measurable outcome. The outcome would be something like 'Material Recovery Rate' or 'Tracking Accuracy'. Material Tracking is what practitioners DO to enable circularity and material reuse.
This refers to the obstacle/challenge of relying on virgin materials rather than recycled/reused materials in construction - it is a barrier to circular economy practices
This refers to the actual physical materials that are newly extracted/manufactured rather than recycled - it is a material asset category
This represents the positive capability or practice of sharing information, which facilitates deconstruction and circular economy activities.

This represents the specific obstacle of inadequate or insufficient information sharing, which is a distinct concept from the enabler. The qualifier 'weak' makes this a barrier rather than an enabler.

These refer to the same concept - the phase in a building's lifecycle when it is in active use. This is a Practice (a stage of activity in the building lifecycle) rather than a Requirement (which would be a specific obligation). The terms 'Operation Phase' and 'Operational Phase' are synonymous, with 'Operation Phase' being the more standard terminology in building lifecycle management.

These refer to the same concept - the practice of conducting audits before demolition to assess materials and components. While pre-demolition audits can be required by regulations, the entity itself represents the actual practice/action of performing these audits. The primary nature is a Practice (something practitioners DO), though it may be mandated as a requirement in various jurisdictions.
Product stewardship is a practice - an approach where producers take responsibility for the lifecycle of their products. This is something stakeholders DO.

Product stewardship schemes are specific policy instruments or programs that formalize and mandate product stewardship practices. These are distinct from the general practice itself - they are the regulatory/policy mechanisms that implement or require the practice.
This refers to the physical material - bricks that have been recycled and are available as a resource
This refers to the action/process of recycling bricks - a specific method used in construction/deconstruction
This is a broad enabling factor that facilitates sustainable construction practices. It encompasses both energy and material sources as a combined enabler.

This specifically refers to the physical materials themselves (e.g., bamboo, timber, bio-based materials) that can be renewed. This is distinct from the broader concept of renewable sources as an enabler. These are different concepts: one is about the materials themselves, the other is about the availability of renewable sources as a systemic enabler.

These refer to the same core practice of extending material/component life through repair and reuse. 'Use, Reuse and Repair' includes 'Use' which is implicit in any practice context. The canonical form 'Repair and Reuse' is more concise and follows standard terminology in circular economy literature, where these are the key operational practices. Both describe the same action-oriented approach to material management.

These refer to the same concept - the capacity of systems to withstand and recover from disruptions. 'Systemic Resilience' is simply a more specific formulation of 'Resilience' in the context of building/construction systems. The correct type is OutcomeMetric because resilience is a measurable result or characteristic that governance frameworks aim to achieve, not something that enables other outcomes. It represents a desired state or performance indicator of the built environment system.

Resource Efficiency is fundamentally a measurable outcome in the circular economy and deconstruction context - it quantifies how effectively resources are used. While improved resource efficiency can enable further circular practices, its primary function in governance is as a metric to assess performance and progress. It measures the ratio of value created to resources consumed, making it an OutcomeMetric.

Both refer to the same physical infrastructure concept - facilities where deconstructed materials and components are stored. This is a MaterialAsset (physical resource/infrastructure) rather than a Practice (action) or Enabler (facilitating factor). The storage facilities themselves are the tangible asset that enables material reuse in the circular economy.
This is a specific design approach/method used in construction - clearly a Practice
This refers to measurable results from sustainable design/build practices - clearly an OutcomeMetric, distinct from the practice itself

As-built drawings are specific documentation artifacts (physical or digital records) that capture the final constructed state of a building. They are material information assets used in deconstruction planning, not a practice (which would be 'creating as-built drawings') nor an instrument (which would be a policy/law). They function as tangible resources that enable deconstruction activities.

groups.canonical_label: Closing the Loop: Waste Reforms for a Circular Economy
members: Closing the Loop: Waste Reforms for a Circular Economy [Instrument]
groups.reasoning: This is a specific named policy document/reform package, making it an Instrument

groups.canonical_label: Waste Innovation for a Circular Economy
members: Waste innovation for a circular economy [Practice]
groups.reasoning: This refers to innovative approaches and methods in waste management, making it a Practice rather than a specific policy instrument. These are distinct concepts - one is a specific policy document, the other is a general practice area
This is a specific EU directive (2008/98/EC) that establishes the legal framework for waste management in the EU. It is correctly typed as an Instrument.

These are specific measurable targets (e.g., percentage reductions in waste generation) that are SET BY the Waste Framework Directive but are distinct from the directive itself. They represent quantifiable outcomes and are correctly typed as OutcomeMetric.

These refer to the same concept - a formal documented plan for systematically deconstructing a building. 'Deconstruction Plan' and 'Dismantling Plan' are synonymous terms used in different jurisdictions/contexts. The correct type is Instrument because it is a specific named policy document/deliverable required by regulations, not merely a requirement itself. The plan is the instrument that contains requirements.
This is a specific policy instrument - a financial mechanism (levy/tax) applied to demolition activities

This is a distinct entity - it refers to the research/analysis activity (a practice) of studying whether a demolition levy is viable, not the levy itself. It's an investigative action, not a requirement or the instrument being studied
This is a specific requirement within the LEED certification system related to materials (MAT 01 credit)
This is a distinct specific requirement within the LEED certification system related to materials (MAT 06 credit), separate from MAT 01

These refer to the same concept - formal standards that govern materials and products in construction. 'Material and Product Standards' is more complete and accurate. The correct type is Instrument because standards are specific named policy tools/frameworks that establish requirements, rather than being requirements themselves. Standards are documents that contain multiple requirements within them.
